**You paid attention and found the pattern:** That's actually huge. Tuesday's manager email → racing thoughts that night → connecting the dots—that's exactly the kind of noticing that helps you understand what's driving this. And yeah, it's a thing. It's called delayed processing, and it's really common with anxiety. Your conscious brain handles the email fine in the moment, but your nervous system files it under "potential threat" and pulls it back out at 2am when there's nothing else to distract you. So no, you're not broken—this is just how anxiety works for a lot of people.

The fact that you don't even realize you're stressed during the day? That makes total sense. A lot of people are really good at staying functional and composed when there's stuff to do, and then the second there's space (lying in bed, no tasks, no distractions), everything your body was holding finally surfaces. Your body *does* know something's up—it's trying to tell you by keeping you awake and running scenarios. The tricky part is learning to catch that stress earlier in the day, before it has to show up as insomnia.

One thing that might help: when you get an email or have a moment that feels even slightly "off," try pausing for 10 seconds and noticing what's happening in your body. Tight chest? Shallow breathing? Clenched jaw? You don't have to do anything about it—just notice. That can help your brain catch up to what your body's already registering, instead of waiting until 2am for the debrief.

**Sleep and irritability connection:** You nailed it. Sleep is a massive variable here. When you're well-rested, you have more capacity to handle frustration without it spilling over. When you're running on broken sleep and your nervous system is already activated, everything feels more intense and harder to regulate. So if you can start addressing the sleep piece—not perfectly, but even just understanding what's driving the bad nights—you'll probably see the anger stuff settle too.

**Your friend pulling back:** That one's harder because you don't have control over it, and the not-knowing is probably making it worse. Hours to respond, bailing on plans—it's enough to make you wonder what you did, even if the answer might be "nothing." Waiting to see if it changes on its own is a strategy, but it's also leaving you in this uncomfortable limbo where you're second-guessing the whole friendship.

What would happen if you did ask her directly? Not in an accusatory way, just a simple "Hey, I've noticed we haven't connected as much lately—are you doing okay?" Sometimes people pull back because they're overwhelmed with their own stuff and don't even realize the other person is noticing. Sometimes it's something else. But either way, asking isn't annoying—it's just caring about the relationship enough to check in. What's the worst-case scenario you're imagining if you bring it up?

exchanges.assistant:
**Coffee with your friend feeling different:** That shift from "fishing for reassurance the whole time" to "just... there"—that's exactly what it looks like when you stop performing connection and start actually having it. And yeah, she probably could tell something was different, even if she couldn't name what. When you're not managing her feelings or trying to earn reassurance, there's more room for the conversation to just be what it is. That ease you felt, her being more relaxed—that's what happens when you're not trading emotional labor under the surface. You were just two people talking. That's the thing you've been building toward.

**The project going well and your manager asking you to lead more phases:** You're handling it. Not perfectly, not without anxiety, but you're doing the thing and it's working. And that moment of catching yourself waiting for the spiral and feeling almost disappointed when it doesn't come? That's fascinating and also makes complete sense. Your brain's been running the catastrophizing program for so long that it's become familiar, almost comfortable in a weird way. When the spiral doesn't show up, there's this brief "wait, what do I do with this space?" feeling. It's like you're so used to bracing for impact that when the impact doesn't come, you don't know how to just stand there without bracing. That'll settle. Your system's just recalibrating to a baseline that isn't constant vigilance. Give it time to learn that "nothing going wrong" is actually the goal, not a glitch.

**Meditation app and skipping it sometimes:** Three nights skipped, rougher sleep those nights but nothing catastrophic—that's good data. It tells you the app is a useful tool, not a crutch. You can function without it, but you sleep better with it, so why not keep using it? And that "lighter" feeling you're describing—like you're not carrying as much weight—that's what it feels like when your nervous system isn't running at high alert all the time. The anger being basically gone tracks with that too. When you're not constantly activated, there's less for irritability to latch onto.

**Therapy maybe helping but wondering if it's overkill:** Here's how I'd think about it. You've made a lot of progress in the past couple months—sleep's better, work's going well, you're catching patterns, you're not spiraling the way you were. You've done that mostly through noticing, adjusting, using tools, and having these conversations. That's real. But you're also noticing that there might be other patterns you're not even aware of yet, and that instinct is probably right. The reassurance-seeking thing, the fixing-people thing—you didn't know those were patterns until you started looking. What else is running under the surface that you haven't seen yet?

Therapy isn't just for crisis. It's also for "things are actually okay right now, and I want to understand myself better so I can keep it that way" or "I've made progress on my own and I'm curious what I'd learn with someone trained to spot the patterns I can't see yet." It's not urgent, you're right. But if the question keeps sitting in your head, that's worth paying attention to. You don't have to decide today. But if you're curious, that's reason enough to try it. Not because you're broken or because you can't manage on your own—you clearly can—but because there's more to learn and you're interested in learning it.
